creditline: The Linda and Lawrence Perlman Photography Endowment
description: color photograph of a corner of a room with white walls, dark wood trim, woven floor mats, with a large bulletin board on the wall; on the bulletin board are album covers for primarily American musicians; arrived in a white wood frame with cleats
markings: gallery label frame verso BL: ShugoArts
text: The series “Japanese House” by Tomoko Yoneda aligns with the artist’s long-held interest in sites with layered histories. She brings us into buildings in Taiwan, built during the island’s Japanese occupation (1895–1945) that still retain the Japanese architectural style of the 1920s and 30s. Over time, however, their interiors have undergone significant changes. The home of a child of a former Japanese government official, for instance, becomes a gathering place for music-related posters. The past and the present poetically co-exist in Yoneda’s photograph, providing a glimpse of the lives of those who inhabited these spaces and how in their re-use, they take on new meanings.
title: Former residence of the daughter of Japanese Prime Minister, Kantaro Suzuki who accepted the Potsdam Declaration and full surrender to the Allied Powers ending the Second World War, Qingtian Street, II
